column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Tsunami
#Text=A tsunami is a giant wave hitting the coast .
#Text=It is usually caused by an earthquake or underwater landslide ( also often caused by an earthquake ) .

#Text=At sea the wave is hardly noticeable , but when it is slowed down by a shallow area , such as near the coastline , it becomes steeper and can rise to a height of tens of meters , with an enormous destructive force .
#Text=Understand
#Text=If the epicenter of an earthquake is under the ocean or a large lake , the earthquake will move huge amounts of water .
#Text=Even a small earthquake can also cause an underwater landslide , with similar effects .
#Text=The tsunami risk depends on in what direction the water is moved .
#Text=In the worst case , such as when the edge of a tectonic moves up- or downwards along the plate boundary , the water will move more or less in a coordinated direction , causing a huge wave .
#Text=Tsunamis can strike the coast minutes or hours after an earthquake , depending on how far away from the coast the epicenter was .
#Text=Tsunamis may travel as fast as a commercial jet and are often invisible before it is too late , as they grow in height only as they hit the shallower waters near the coast .

#Text=Moreover , tsunamis can travel very far – for instance the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami was caused by an earthquake north of Sumatra but also wreaked havoc on the east coast of Africa several hours later .
#Text=There has long been a tsunami warning center for the Pacific Ocean and after the 2004 tsunami one was installed for the Indian Ocean as well .

#Text=Although they are not perfect and false alarms do occur , their warnings should be heeded , as the worst that can happen in case of a false alarm is a ruined day , while a tsunami can easily kill you and your company .
#Text=Natural warning signs

#Text=Should you find yourself in the unlikely situation of a tsunami where there is no warning infrastructure , there are usually what are referred to as " natural warning signs " – nature itself telling you that a tsunami is coming .
#Text=If an earthquake occurs right on the coast you may only have a matter of minutes to escape , so do n't hesitate to evacuate .
#Text=Some noticeable natural warning signs are :
#Text=Strange behavior in animals such as restlessness ( may or may not occur )

#Text=Water receding and exposing ocean floor that is usually under water at all times ( this is a dead giveaway that the tsunami is imminent and you have , at best , a couple of minutes to flee from this point on )

#Text=Notable shocks of an earthquake off or close to the coast ( if you are at the coast and feel an earthquake , do n't wait for any official warnings , but head inland or to higher ground immediately )
#Text=Loud or unusual noises coming from the sea
#Text=During a tsunami

#Text=During a tsunami warning , follow the escape routes and pay close attention to what the authorities are saying as they are usually ( especially in countries with a Pacific coast line ) well aware of the nature of a tsunami and have refined their emergency plans with earlier tsunamis .
#Text=The most important thing during a tsunami is obviously to get to high ground .

#Text=However , trees and even the roofs of houses are a sub-par alternative to mountains as the enormous force of the tsunami may simply destroy the tree or even the house you are seeking shelter in ( or on the top of ) .
#Text=Under no circumstances should you count on your swimming ability against such a powerful current !
#Text=If the absolute worst happens and you are swept away by the water , try to hold onto a floating piece of debris and await rescue .
#Text=Do not go to the coast to sight-see or watch for a tsunami !
#Text=During the tsunami of March 2011 triggered by the Tōhoku earthquake , a 25-year-old man was swept into the Pacific Ocean near the Klamath River in Northern California .
#Text=The man and some friends had travelled to the shoreline to take photos of the incoming waves - his friends survived , but the man 's body was never found .
#Text=After a tsunami
#Text=Be aware that there may be more than one tsunami wave and they can occur up to 24 hours after the initial wave , so remain evacuated until you are told by officials that it is safe to return .
#Text=When returning to buildings , be aware that floodwaters may have caused serious damage to infrastructure .
#Text=Floodwater may also be contaminated with sewage .
#Text=Avoid sightseeing and only travel if necessary .
#Text=If you have made travel arrangements with an airline or otherwise , it is best to contact them for advice .
#Text=See also
#Text=Earthquakes
